GameEngine
Class Game.GameDrawer

java.lang.Object
  GameEngine.Game.GameDrawer
Enclosing class:
Game
public class Game.GameDrawer
extends java.lang.Object

This class is your interface to the OpenGL rendering capabilities.

You may specify offsets which will offset anything you draw by that amount. This will effectively shift your entire game world by a certain amount. Useful for scrolling around your screen.

The draw method draws the specified shape using a list of points given. The shape can be one of LINES, TRIANGLES, QUADS, POINTS Multiple shapes of the same type can be drawn using one call of the draw method. If insufficient points are provided the shape will not be drawn.

For example if you specify QUADS and provide 4 points. 1 QUAD will be drawn. (QUADS require 4 points to be specified)

If you specify QUADS and provide 12 points. 3 QUADS will be drawn. The first QUAD will use points 0-3, the second QUAD will use points 4-7, the third QUAD will use points 8-11

If you specify QUADS to be drawn and only give an array of 3 points the QUAD will not be drawn.

If you specify QUADS and provide 7 points the first quad will be drawn but since there are only 3 points left the second QUAD will not.

You may also use the draw method to draw a polygon or a line strip (a string of lines). Only one polygon or line strip will be drawn per call of the draw method

For those who know OpenGL these 'shapes' correspond to the types of things that can be rendered in OpenGL (i.e. QUADS corresponds to GL_QUADS). I can add support for drawing of GL_LINE_LOOP, GL_TRIANGLE_STRIP, GL_TRIANGLE_FAN and GL_QUAD_STRIP if there is a demand for it.

The drawing of fonts actually happens after the renderStep method has finished. They are buffered into an array of Stack objects and drawn all at once afterwards. This is partly is because of how JOGL's inbuilt Font rendering is set up, and partly because of the design of the API.

All the strings of text are grouped with their respective fonts and then rendered font by font in the order the GameFont object were created in the initStep method. This is only an issue if your text is goin to be transparent in anyway, otherwise you can use it as normal.

Parameters:
c - A float [4] specifying the red, green, blue, alpha channels respectively.

draw

public void draw(GameObject o,
                 float depth)
Draws a GameObject at a specified depth with whatever colour is currently set. The game object will be drawn at it's internally specified position, center and with it's current active texture.

Parameters:
o - The GameObject to be drawn
depth - The depth at which to draw the GameObject, a lower number means it will be behind other objects

draw

public void draw(GameObject o,
                 float[] c,
                 float depth)
Draws a GameObject at a specified depth with specified colour. The game object will be drawn at it's internally specified position, center and with it's current active texture.

This is equivalent to calling setColour (float [] c); draw (GameObject o, float depth) ;

Parameters:
o - The GameObject to be drawn
c - A float [4] specifying the red, green, blue, alpha channels respectively.
depth - The depth at which to draw the GameObject, a lower number means it will be behind other objects

draw

public void draw(int type,
                 java.awt.geom.Point2D.Float[] points,
                 float depth)
Draws a specified shape (possibly zero or multiple times) with a given array of points at a specified depth with the currently set colour.

See class description for more details

Parameters:
type - The type of shape to draw. One of LINES, TRIANGLES, QUADS, POINTS, POLYGON or LINE_STRIP
points - The list of points (or vertexes)
depth - The depth at which to draw the shape(s), a lower number means it will be behind other objects

draw

public void draw(int type,
                 java.awt.geom.Point2D.Float[] points,
                 float[][] c,
                 float depth)
Draws a specified shape (possibly zero or multiple times) with a given array of points at a specified depth with the specified colors. The array of floats should be the same length (or longer) then the length of the array of points. Each point will be assigned the colour specified at the corresponding index of the colour array. This allows one to specify different colours at different vertexes. Colours will fade into one another and will for a gradient.

E.g: points[50] will get the colour values set at c[50]

See class description for more details

Parameters:
type - The type of shape to draw. One of LINES, TRIANGLES, QUADS, POINTS, POLYGON or LINE_STRIP
points - The list of points (or vertexes)
c - The list of corresponding colours. Should be an array of float [4]
depth - The depth at which to draw the shape(s), a lower number means it will be behind other objects

draw

public void draw(int type,
                 java.awt.geom.Point2D.Float[] points,
                 float r,
                 float g,
                 float b,
                 float a,
                 float depth)
Draws a specified shape (possibly zero or multiple times) with a given array of points at a specified depth with the specified colour.

This is equivalent to calling setColour (float r, float g, float b, float a); draw(int type, Point2D.Float [] points, float depth);

See class description for more details

Parameters:
type - The type of shape to draw. One of LINES, TRIANGLES, QUADS, POINTS, POLYGON or LINE_STRIP
points - The list of points (or vertexes)
r - Value of the red channel (between 0.0 and 1.0)
g - Value of the green channel (between 0.0 and 1.0)
b - Value of the blue channel (between 0.0 and 1.0)
a - Value of the alpha channel (between 0.0 and 1.0)
depth - The depth at which to draw the shape(s), a lower number means it will be behind other objects

draw

public void draw(GameFont gf,
                 java.lang.String text,
                 java.awt.geom.Point2D.Float point,
                 float depth)
Draws a String in the specified font (described by a GameFont object) at a specified position and depth.

Parameters:
gf - The GameFont that hold the desired font to render with
text - The text to be rendered
point - The position of the lower left corner of the text to be drawn
depth - The depth at which to draw the shape(s), a lower number means it will be behind other objects

draw

public void draw(GameFont gf,
                 java.lang.String text,
                 java.awt.geom.Point2D.Float point,
                 float depth,
                 float scale)
Draws a String in the specified font (described by a GameFont object) at a specified position and depth, scaled to a percentage of it's origional size. Note that the scaling is intended for minor adjustments, scalling too big will cause blocky text and scaling too small with create aliasing artifacts. Rather create another font with smaller or higher size.

Parameters:
gf - The GameFont that hold the desired font to render with
text - The text to be rendered
point - The position of the lower left corner of the text to be drawn
depth - The depth at which to draw the shape(s), a lower number means it will be behind other objects
scale - What percentage scaling this text should be rendered at (1.0 means the same size, 2.0 means double size etc)

draw

public void draw(GameFont gf,
                 java.lang.String text,
                 java.awt.geom.Point2D.Float point,
                 float[] c,
                 float depth)
Draws a String in the specified font (described by a GameFont object) at a specified position, colour and depth.

Parameters:
gf - The GameFont that hold the desired font to render with
text - The text to be rendered
point - The position of the lower left corner of the text to be drawn
c - A float [4] specifying the red, green, blue, alpha channels respectively.
depth - The depth at which to draw the shape(s), a lower number means it will be behind other objects

                 float a,

Draws a String in the specified font (described by a GameFont object) at a certain position, colour and depth, scaled to a percentage of it's origional size. Note that the scaling is intended for minor adjustments, scalling too big will cause blocky text and scaling too small with create aliasing artifacts. Rather create another font with smaller or higher size.

Parameters:
gf - The GameFont that hold the desired font to render with
text - The text to be rendered
point - The position of the lower left corner of the text to be drawn
r - Value of the red channel (between 0.0 and 1.0)
g - Value of the green channel (between 0.0 and 1.0)
b - Value of the blue channel (between 0.0 and 1.0)
a - Value of the alpha channel (between 0.0 and 1.0)
depth - The depth at which to draw the shape(s), a lower number means it will be behind other objects
scale - What percentage scaling this text should be rendered at (1.0 means the same size, 2.0 means double size etc)
